awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Collaborative Research: HEECMA: A Hybrid Elastic Edge-Cloud Application Management Architecture
awd_abstract_narration:
Application software is becoming increasingly abundant in functionality and increasingly demanding of resources, e.g., memory and compute power. This project examines how application software, e.g., a Virtual Reality (VR) based drone control application, can be partitioned and deployed over different parts of a distributed computing infrastructure, i.e., resources are managed by a hybrid of service and cloud providers. Research questions that will be answered include: what is the best partitioning of the application that balances compute and memory demand for each application component (function) and the communication needs between these functions? Which provider should be used for each application function so that it runs quickly at the lowest cost? Moreover, how should the system adapt to changes in the availability of resources to maintain a high level of quality of experience for users?

The project will develop the theoretical foundations of decomposing applications over a distributed complex cyberinfrastructure. We will study various decompositions and corresponding virtualization and resource allocation services offered by different providers with resources at the edge of the infrastructure, i.e., closer to users, and at the core, i.e., deeper into the infrastructure. The goal is to find the "best" decomposition to meet users' quality of experience while reducing the cost/price for the users. The decomposed (distributed) solution will be realized by employing corresponding feedback control algorithms and game-theoretic incentives.  The project will then experiment with three classes of applications to validate these theoretical foundations: streaming Augmented/Virtual Reality (AR/VR), intrusion detection, and spatiotemporal ecological forecasting. Toward this end, a prototype will be developed and evaluated over existing open cloud infrastructures (e.g., GENI, CloudLab, Chameleon), commercial clouds, as well as private clouds (e.g., Massachusetts Open Cloud).

This project will advance the state of the art in the area of application software decomposition and deployment over large-scale hybrid cloud infrastructures.  The theoretical foundations and experimental validation of the work will inform the design and deployment of other foreseen and unforeseen applications. The performance and cost gains will translate to more efficient use of resources and consequently, a society that is better connected and greener. Outreach efforts will include several activities: (1) the development and delivery of hands-on tutorials that involve partitioning and running application software over a distributed cyberinfrastructure managed by multiple providers, (2) the organization of annual summer camps on cyberinfrastructure operations and management for high school students, and (3) the training and mentoring of minority and under-represented students working on research related to this project. 

The project will maintain a website at http://csr.bu.edu/heecma for the duration of this grant and beyond. The website will contain all the publications and results of this project in the form of code, prototype, and tutorials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The HEECMA project tackled the challenge of building future-ready networks to support emerging applications, such as virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR), autonomous systems, drones, and healthcare technologies. These applications require extremely fast data transfer (over 500 Mbps) and ultra-low latency (less than 5 milliseconds). However, current cloud infrastructures, with delays between 20 and 100 milliseconds, cannot meet these stringent requirements. To address this, our research focused on decomposing applications into smaller virtual functions (VFs) and distributing them across edge and cloud environments to enhance performance, security, and scalability. Key use cases explored have been:

  1. Ultra-low latency, high-bandwidth applications like AR/VR systems.
  2. Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) to detect cybersecurity threats in real time.
  3. Big data applications that process large datasets, such as ecological forecasting and network monitoring.

 

Intellectual Merit: Key Outcomes and Achievements

 

1. Privacy and Efficiency in Federated Split Learning

In collaboration with Boston University (BU), we designed a hybrid Federated Split Learning architecture to enhance both privacy and performance in distributed machine learning. Submitted to IEEE Transactions on Big Data, the research highlighted how this model lowers client-side processing requirements while maintaining high accuracy, making it ideal for privacy-sensitive applications like healthcare. We also developed the Distributed Training Simulator (DTS) to evaluate the performance of various distributed learning architectures, including Pipeline Learning and Split Learning.

2. Federated Learning for Network Optimization

One of the project's early milestones was Blaster, a federated learning-based routing system for software-defined networks (SDN), presented at IEEE NetSoft 2020. Blaster optimized communication between SDN controllers, reducing bandwidth consumption while maintaining high-quality routing. This achievement aligns with the project's goal to efficiently manage next-generation networks.

3. Optimized Cuckoo Filters for Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS)

To enhance network traffic management, we developed the Optimized Cuckoo Filter (OCF), which addresses the performance limitations of traditional Bloom filters. Presented at IEEE NFV-SDN 2020, OCFs improved tasks like network caching and forwarding in SDN-based IDS systems. Simulations demonstrated OCF's ability to manage network traffic more efficiently with reduced overhead.

4. Accelerating Federated Learning via In-Network Processing

To overcome synchronization and bandwidth challenges in federated learning, we proposed a novel model using P4 programmable switches. This model, developed in collaboration with Politecnico di Torino, performed gradient aggregation at intermediate nodes, reducing network overhead and improving training speeds. The solution enabled scalable deployment across IoT networks.

5. MLOps Orchestration and Network Traffic Prediction

We introduced Plebiscito, an orchestration system for machine learning operations (MLOps) across edge computing environments. Plebiscito employs an asynchronous max-consensus protocol to optimize task distribution under resource constraints. Additionally, in partnership with BU, we developed ResCue, a federated learning framework that uses deep residual networks to predict network traffic patterns. ResCue enhances traffic management, even with incomplete network data, providing a real-world solution to network telemetry challenges.

6. Supporting AR/VR Applications and National Security

In collaboration with the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA), we created EdgeVerse, a multi-user VR environment powered by edge computing. This project explored how immersive VR can transform the "Future of Work" in national security. We also designed cloud-based VR rendering solutions that offload computational tasks, predict Field of View (FOV), and reduce bandwidth needs, ensuring seamless virtual experiences.

 

Broader Impacts: Real-World Applications and Workforce Development

Training Future Experts

This project provided hands-on research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at Saint Louis University (SLU) and international collaborators from Italy, France, and Brazil. Students gained experience in distributed AI, machine learning, and network virtualization by working on prototypes and publications. Collaborations with NGA exposed students to real-world challenges in national security and geospatial intelligence. The project helped prepare students for careers in advanced technology fields by integrating prototypes and tools into SLU's curriculum.

International Collaborations and Innovation

The project fostered global partnerships with institutions like Politecnico di Torino, the University of Pisa, and Boston University. One example of the project's impact is the return of former visiting scholar Emilio Paolini to SLU's Networking Lab under an EU Next Generation Internet (NGI) fellowship to continue his research, underscoring the international significance of this work.

Industry Collaboration and Societal Impact

The project's interdisciplinary research also included collaboration with Agrela Ecosystems, a spinoff from the Danforth Plant Science Center. Together, we explored how IoT devices and AI could enhance agricultural monitoring, demonstrating the broader societal value of our research across industries.
